title: What is your favorite and most useful dingbat glyph?
content:
I'm working on a collection of dingbats to go with my [OverKill](http://web.archive.org/web/20100202002913/http:/new.myfonts.com/fonts/fontry-west/jls-over-kill-bloque/) fonts. This collection will be designed to go with most extra bold or black weight fonts, not just OverKill. I've researched other dingbat fonts and there is a lot of stuff that is useless (in my opinion). I wanted ask what dingbat glyphs other folks find useful and how they might be used. For instance, I saw a cool one the other day. On the side of a service van, there was a computer mouse at the front of the web address. I'm certain that it isn't new, I just hadn't noticed it.

Thanks  
James

~~~~~~~~~~~~~

[_...from the Fontry_](http://web.archive.org/web/20100202002913/http:/www.thefontry.com/)
author: phrostbyte64

comments.content:
That's a interesting project: ultra-bold dingbats, I like it! :-)  
The problem with dingbats, as I see it, is that is difficult to strike the right balance between specificity/specialisation (and, thus, usefulness) and a broader scope (thus a broader audience).  
One thing I would find useful, for example, would be a set of dingbats that can be used to mark the different entries of a business card/contact form (address, telephone number, fax number, e-mail, etc.).  
I noticed also that often dingbats in the same collection have a difficult time sharing a common distinctive style.

_riccardo: I noticed also that often dingbats in the same collection have a difficult time sharing a common distinctive style._

That is one of the problems I am trying to address. Thanks for your input.

~~~~~~~~~~~~~

[_...from the Fontry_](http://web.archive.org/web/20100202002913/http:/www.thefontry.com/)
